title: Veral's article that the lottery winner was arrested for drowning manure on the grass of the former president smells like fakes.
text: A viral blog claims that a man who won the lottery was arrested "because he received $224,000 worth of fertilizer on the property of his former employer." Published in World News Daily Report, the article claims that 54-year-old Clarendon Hills, Brian Morris, bought over 20,000 tons of compost after winning $125 million in the Powerball multistate lottery two weeks ago. This story was highlighted as part of Facebook ' s efforts to combat false news and misleading information in the broadcast of the news. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) This function has received more than 2.3 million interactions and has been shared more than 285,000 times, as shown by Krawdatang data. Clarendon Hills is a village in and the county seat of the U.S. state of Illinois. The article shows a picture of a guy laughing while he's holding a sign from the Clarandon Hills police department showing his booking number. The search for the picture shows that the image is not for a man named Brian Morris. The photograph is for Ronald Cyril, who was arrested in 2014 for driving under influence, according to WGN9. Another photo is posted on the daily World News Report, which is for two police officers. An article published by Chicago Tribune on May 16, 2018, indicates that the photograph was taken by the recently retired Chief of Police, Clarendon Hills, Paul Dahlan, and Chief of Police, Boyd Farmer. All the characters appearing in the articles on this site - even those based on real people - are quite fictional and any resemblance to anyone, alive, dead or not, is purely a miracle. The Politi Fact found the stories of the World News Daily Report false before. However, the trick has made a real difference. According to the Chicago Tribune, this position was circulated throughout the Clarendon Hills community, and the Police Department received some of the calls it inquired about in May. "I think it's a little funny, but people need to read to the bottom and know it's not a real news story," said village president Lin Austin in Chicago Tribune at the time. "The problem these days is that people see a headline on the Internet and jump to conclusions."
